The theme of the conference is to examine critically the depth and sphere of involvement and to explore the [...] University of Oxford CPD Centre 2014-10-30T10:06:03+00:00 2014-10-30T10:06:03+00:00 University of Oxford Accredited Short Course: Qualitative Research Methods, 29 June\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd3 July 2015 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Only six places left https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CMHN-EDUCATION-AND-PRACTICE;f3f64d2d.1410 Exploring qualitative research through interviews<br><br>This module will provide an overview of the principles and practice of qualitative research. Students will explore how people make sense of their lives, and recognise ways in which qualitative research bridges the gap between scientific evidence and clinical practice by examining the attitudes, beliefs, and preferences of both patients and practitioners. Participants will learn to collect data using observation, interview and focus groups and become familiar with the techniques of thematic qualitative data analysis. The team welcome abstracts reporting on innovations in technology enhanced learning within medical education. This could include the development of electronic materials as well as medical education research. Further details on abstract submissions including the categories and the types of presentation opportunities can be found on the QUB website<http://www.med.qub.ac.uk/TEL/abstract.html>. The rich and<br><br>intensive programme will be delivered by internationally renowned experts through keynote lectures, fora, group<br><br>sessions and one-to-one tutorials covering the following themes: [...] Paul Taylor 2014-08-22T16:11:40+01:00 2014-08-22T16:11:40+01:00 New Publication- Criminal Justice, Mental Health and Risk https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CMHN-EDUCATION-AND-PRACTICE;cfc9912f.1408 Apologies for cross-posting<br><br>The following text, released in October 2014, may be of interest to those working/studying/researching/teaching in the areas of Criminology, Criminal Justice, Social Work, Sociology, Mental Health Nursing or Psychiatry. A Companion to Criminal Justice, Mental Health and Risk provides succinct and critical definitions to key terms and themes in the converging areas of mental health, criminal justice and risk. It outlines the conceptual and practical challenges that exist through the collection of over 180 different entries of no more than 800 words in length, each written by academics, practitioners and policy writers who are experts in their [...] Healthandsocialcare 2014-07-02T11:37:12+00:00 2014-07-02T11:37:12+00:00 Free places left on the Mask-Ed tour - in the North East of England https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CMHN-EDUCATION-AND-PRACTICE;46d3ab7c.1407 **With apologies for cross-posting**<br><br>Dear Colleagues<br><br>Are you looking for innovative ways to engage your students?<br><br>Pioneering international healthcare educator Kerry Reid-Searl, CQ University, Australia is nearing the end of her UK tour - there are still spaces available for interested parties in the North East of England.<br><br>Kerry has become known internationally for her work in creating, designing, implementing and researching an innovative simulation strategy called Mask-Ed (KRS Simulation). This simulation technique, through the use of silicone props, transforms the expert educator/ professional into a character who in-turn becomes the platform for learning and teaching. Kerry is also well [...] University of Oxford CPD Centre 2014-04-14T15:47:08+01:00 2014-04-14T15:47:08+01:00 Oxford University, Knowledge into Action: Fellows learn to use research to improve local clinical practice https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CMHN-EDUCATION-AND-PRACTICE;a02e0e18.1404 Fellows learn to use research to improve local clinical practice<br><br>Dr Sharon Mickan http://cebmlearning.org/2014/03/06/fellows-learn-to-use-research-to-improve-local-clinical-practice/ reviews the evidence that education using evidence-based health care principles improves participants\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd knowledge, critical appraisal skills and their ability to integrate research into decisions.<br><br>Dr Mickan runs Oxford's course Knowledge into Action www.conted.ox.ac.uk/kia (2-6 June 2014). The course has been designed for health professionals to support the development of critical appraisal skills, and includes using research evidence to inform decisions and identifying local barriers and facilitators to improve clinical care. It also forms part of Oxford's part-time MSc in Evidence-Based Health Care www.conted.ox.ac.uk/ebhc [...]
